tit.e: Nenyo (one of the position in the In's (retired emperor's) office
Nenyo (one of the positions in the In's or retired emperor's) office
Nenyo (one of the positions in the In's or retired emperor's) office

sen.j: 年預（ねんよ）は、中世日本に置かれた役職の1つ。
sen.e: The Nenyo is an official position during the middle ages in Japan.
The Nenyo was an official position during the middle ages in Japan.
The Nenyo was an official position during the middle ages in Japan.

sen.j: 年預（ねんよ）は、院司に置かれた役職の1つ。
sen.e: The Nenyo is an official position in the Inshi (officials of the In no cho, or Retired Emperor's Office)
The Nenyo is an official position in the Inshi (officials of the In no cho, or Retired Emperor's Office)
The Nenyo is an official position in the Inshi (officials of the In no cho, or Retired Emperor's Office)

sen.j: 院庁を監督して院中の事務執行を担当する責任者である。
sen.e: The Nenyo supervised the In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office) and took the responsibility for running administrative affairs in the In.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Nenyo supervised the In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office) and took the responsibility for running administrative affairs in the In.
The Nenyo supervised the In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office) and took the responsibility for running administrative affairs in the In.

sen.j: 四位・五位の受領が別当を務めて院年預（いんのねんよ）あるいは年預別当（ねんよべっとう）と呼称されるのが恒例であった。
sen.e: The Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) of the fourth or fifth Court Ranks worked as a Betto (chief administrator), which was commonly called "Innonenyo" or "Nenyo Betto."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Zuryo (head of the provincial governors) of the fourth or fifth Court Ranks worked as a Betto (chief administrator), which was commonly called "Innonenyo" or "Nenyo Betto."
The Zuryo (head of the provincial governors) of the fourth or fifth Court Ranks worked as a Betto (chief administrator), which was commonly called "Innonenyo" or "Nenyo Betto."

sen.j: 後には院の執事や執権がこれを兼務する場合もあった。
sen.e: In later years, some stewards or regents served concurrently as Nenyo.
In later years, some stewards or regents served concurrently as Nenyo.
In later years, some stewards or regents served concurrently as Nenyo.

sen.j: 著名な年預に白河天皇の藤原基隆、鳥羽天皇の藤原忠隆、後白河天皇の藤原俊盛、美福門院の平忠盛などがいる。
sen.e: Prominent Nenyo includes FUJIWARA no Mototaka under Emperor Shirakawa, FUJIWARA no Tadataka under Emperor Toba, FUJIWARA no Toshimori under Emperor Goshirakawa, and TAIRA no Tadamori under Bifukumon-in.

Prominent Nenyo includes FUJIWARA no Mototaka under Emperor Shirakawa, FUJIWARA no Tadataka under Emperor Toba, FUJIWARA no Toshimori under Emperor Goshirakawa, and TAIRA no Tadamori under Bifukumon-in.

Prominent Nenyo includes FUJIWARA no Mototaka under Emperor Shirakawa, FUJIWARA no Tadataka under Emperor Toba, FUJIWARA no Toshimori under Emperor Goshirakawa, and TAIRA no Tadamori under Bifukumon-in.

sen.j: 後に大蔵省・大炊寮と言った正式な官司や摂関家家司にも年預が設置された記録が見られる。
sen.e: A historical book described that the position of nenyo was also provided later for government officials such as the Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and Oiryo (Bureau of Palace Kitchens under the Ministry of the Imperial Household) as well as for the Keishi (household superintendent) of the Sekkan Families (Sekkannke).

A historical book described that the position of nenyo was also provided later for government officials such as the Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and Oiryo (Bureau of Palace Kitchens under the Ministry of the Imperial Household) as well as for the Keishi (household superintendent) of the Sekkan Families (Sekkannke).

A historical book described that the position of Nenyo was also provided later for government officials such as the Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and Oiryo (Bureau of Palace Kitchens under the Ministry of the Imperial Household) as well as for the Keishi (household superintendent) of the Sekkan families (Sekkanke).

sen.j: 年預（ねんよ/ねんにょ）は、東大寺・東寺・金剛峯寺などの寺院に置かれた役職の1つ。
sen.e: The Nenyo is an official position in temples such as Todaiji temples, Toji Temple, and Kongobuji Temple.
The Nenyo is an official position in temples such as the Todaiji temple, Toji Temple, and the Kongobuji Temple.
The Nenyo is an official position in temples such as the Todai-ji Temple, To-ji Temple, and the Kongobu-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: ハイフン挿入スペルを修正

sen.j: 大衆_(仏教)による集会評定の幹事となり、集会の開催・進行、決定事項の記録・保管・執行を行う。
sen.e: The Nenyo organized meetings and consultations of the Daishu (Budhist monks residing in the zendo) by arranging and chairing the meetings and recording, storing and putting into practice what was decided in the meetings.

The Nenyo organized meetings and consultations of the Daishu (Budhist monks residing in the zendo) by arranging and chairing the meetings and recording, storing and putting into practice what was decided in the meetings.

The Nenyo organized meetings and consultations of the Daishu (Buddhist monks residing in the zendo) by arranging and chairing the meetings and recording, storing and putting into practice what was decided in the meetings.

sen.j: 大衆の中から1年ごとに籤などで選出されるか、輪番制で交代した。
sen.e: They were elected from the Daishu by drawing lots or held the position by rotation once a year..
They were elected from the Daishu by drawing lots or held the position by rotation once a year..
They were elected from the Daishu by drawing lots or held the position by rotation once a year.

sen.j: 寛平元年に円成寺に置かれたのが最古の記録である。
sen.e: Enjoji Temple set up theNnenyo position in 889, which was the oldest historical record of the position.
Enjoji Temple set up the Nnenyo position in 889, which was the oldest historical record of the position.
Enjo-ji Temple set up the Nenyo position in 889, which was the oldest historical record of the position.
sen.cmt: ハイフン挿入スペルを修正

sen.j: 後にこうした寺院の慣習が武士に対しても影響を与えた。
sen.e: This practice of assigning the Nenyo in temples had an influence on samurai warriors in later years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This practice of assigning Nenyo in temples had an influence on samurai warriors in later years.
This practice of assigning Nenyo in temples had an influence on samurai warriors in later years.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の評定衆や引付衆、月番制などに年預の制度・選出が影響が見られるとされている。
sen.e: The influence of the Nenyo system and its election system is said to be found in the systems of the Kamakura bakufu such as the Hyojoshu (a member of Council of State) and Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) as well as monthly shift or duty system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The influence of the Nenyo system and its election system is said to have been found in the systems of the Kamakura bakufu such as the Hyojoshu (a member of Council of State) and Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) as well as monthly shift or duty system.

The influence of the Nenyo system and its election system is said to have been found in the systems of the Kamakura bakufu such as the Hyojoshu (a member of Council of State) and Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) as well as monthly shift or duty system.
